official-title.#text: To delay implementation of the Mercury and Air Toxics Standards, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
environmental regulations are issued without any economic
			 impact analysis that takes into consideration the costs to comply with
			 such regulations and the impact of such regulations on the local economy
			 and jobs.

environmental regulations are issued without any analysis
			 of the feasibility of compliance with deadlines.

text.#text:
It will cost local communities billions of dollars to comply with the Mercury and Air Toxics
			 Standards.

Communities throughout the Nation will therefore face large increases in their electric utility
			 bills, on top of rising water and wastewater bills, and in some cases
			 these increases in electricity bills could be nearly 20 percent.

The economic impact of such Standards has the potential to be devastating, especially in
			 communities with a high percentage of residents living at or below the
			 poverty line, a factor which is not considered in cost/benefit analyses.

Higher energy costs also threaten all types of businesses, including manufacturing and other
			 industries that employ thousands throughout the Nation.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
